questions.text: Which of the following is true about Factories Act?

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.solution:
Factories act prohibits children of <14 years from being employed.

Children between 15–18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM–7 PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.

The maximum working hours for an adult industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day; if overtime is paid, then it should be not more than 60 hrs per week.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests?

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.solution:
Non-parametric tests are tests that do not assume that the data is normally distributed. Thus, they are used for skewed (asymmetric) distributions {skewed either to the lesser side (left-sided skewed) or towards the greater side (right-sided skewed)}.

The chi-square test is an example of a non-parametric test that is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

ANOVA is an example of a parametric test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which article of the Indian Constitution confers Right to Life to the citizens of India?
questions.solution:
The Right to Life is given in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution.

questions.text: In a well-designed cancer study, similar remission rates were obtained for a new treatment (33.2%) and the usual treatment (32.2%), with the p-value being 0.04. Which of the following statements is true regarding the study?

choices.text: Both the treatments are equally effective
Neither of the treatments is effective
The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment
The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments

questions.solution:
As the p-value is 0.04, we can conclude that the new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment.

Even though both treatments have similar rates of remission, a valid statistical test is required to determine the difference in their effectiveness. Statistically, p-value < 0.05 implies that the alternate hypothesis is true.

In this scenario, we can consider:

  • Null hypothesis: Both the treatments are equally effective (in other terms, there is no difference between the effect of the two treatments).
  • Alternative hypothesis: New treatment is more effective than the usual treatment.

As the p-value is 0.04, which is statistically significant (<0.05), the null hypothesis is rejected and the alternative hypothesis is accepted. Hence the new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby with diarrhea is feeding well and is thirsty. Skin pinch when done returns in 2 seconds. What is the treatment?

choices.text: 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours.
In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool.

questions.solution:
According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has some dehydration and comes under Plan B. The amount of ORS given is 75ml/kg body weight.

Here, the weight of the child is not specified. Hence, 400-700 ml of ORS at home is to be given in the first four hours according to the age of the child. The below table shows the amount of ORS to be given according to the age of the child.

questions.text: What is the ratio of the incidence of the disease in the exposed to that of the non-exposed?
questions.solution:
The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?

NRR: Net reproduction rate
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: In a screening test for DM out of 1000 population, 90 were positive. However, a gold standard test for DM was done of which 100 were positive. Calculate the sensitivity of the screening test?
questions.solution:
The screening test only identified 90 people as positive for diabetes, while the gold standard test identified 100 people. This means that out of the 100 confirmed, 90 have been identified as truly positive by the screening test and 10 are falsely negative. Therefore,

  • True positive = 90
  • False negative = 100-90= 10
  • Sensitivity = TP/(TP+FN) =90/(90+10) = 90/100 = 90%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: The incidence of a disease is 4 per 1000 of the population with an average duration of 2 years.  What is the prevalence?
questions.solution:
The prevelance in the given situation is 8/1000 population.

Prevalence is given by the formula :

Prevalance = Incidence x Mean Duration

Prevalence = 4/1000 x 2 = 8/1000 population

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is known as the_______.
questions.solution:
The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is called secondary attack rate.

It is calculated by the following formula:

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible)

Primary cases are usually excluded from the numerator and denominator.

Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause hardness of water?
questions.solution:
Calcium carbonate does not cause hardness of water. Hardness of water is caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium.

There are two types of hardness of water:

  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of direct transmission of communicable diseases?
questions.solution:
Airborne transmission by droplet nuclei is not a method of direct transmission of diseases.

It is a method of indirect transmission of diseases.

Droplet nuclei are tiny particles of size 1-5 microns range that may be formed by either due to evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air or are formed from aerosols.

These droplet nuclei remain airborne for long periods of time and can transmit diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chickenpox, measles, Q fever and other respiratory infections.

Droplet transmission, vertical transmission, and contact with soil are methods of direct transmission of diseases.

Differences between droplet and droplet nuclei are summarised below:

DROPLET NUCLEI  DROPLET 
Indirect transmission Direct transmission
It is the residue from evaporated droplets It is produced while coughing, sneezing, talking
<5microns in diameter ≥5 microns in diameter
No need for close contact for transmission Requires closeness and direct contact for transmission
Diseases transmitted: chickenpox, measles etc. Diseases transmitted: diphtheria, meningococcal meningitis etc.

questions.text: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines?
questions.solution:
The minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines is 4 weeks.

This is because decreasing the interval between two doses may interfere with the antibody response and protection. Thus, live vaccines can either be given on the same day according to the schedule or 4 weeks apart.

Note: In Park 27th ed. the minimum interval between two live vaccines is given as 3 weeks. However, several other standard sources including CDC and UNDP suggested an interval of 4 weeks. When both are given in options, it is recommended to mark 4 weeks as the correct answer.
